source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_015_chunk1
evidence_span: Cladding specimens were obtained from two fuel rods irradiated in the Big Rock Point Reactor to a burnup of ${ \sim } 8$ gigawatt days per ton.

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_015_chunk1
evidence_span: Both claddings had a uniform, thick $( \sim 4\mu \mathrm { m } )$ zirconium oxide layer on the inner surface.

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_015_chunk1
evidence_span: The significant difference between the two rods was the degree of fission-gas release (0.2 versus 14.3 percent).

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_015_chunk1
evidence_span: The significant difference between the two rods was the degree of fission-gas release (0.2 versus 14.3 percent).

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_015_chunk1
evidence_span: The cladding specimens, with the fuel removed, were subjected to stress-rupture tests in an iodine environment using internal gas pressurization to evaluate their stress corrosion cracking (SCC) susceptibility.

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_015_chunk1
evidence_span: All tests were conducted at an initial iodine concentration of $0 . 6 ~ \mathrm { m g } / \mathrm { c m } ^ { 2 }$ and a temperature of $3 2 5 \mathrm { { \circ C } }$

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_015_chunk1
evidence_span: Specimens from the high-gasrelease rod exhibited significantly increased susceptibility to iodine SCC, with a threshold stress level of ${ \sim } 2 0 0  { \mathbf { M P a } }$ as compared with ${ \sim } 2 8 0  { \mathrm { M P a } }$ in the specimens from the low-gas-release rod.

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_015_chunk1
evidence_span: Specimens from the high-gasrelease rod exhibited significantly increased susceptibility to iodine SCC, with a threshold stress level of ${ \sim } 2 0 0  { \mathbf { M P a } }$ as compared with ${ \sim } 2 8 0  { \mathrm { M P a } }$ in the specimens from the low-gas-release rod.

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_015_chunk1
evidence_span: The results suggest that the inner-surface oxide provides a barrier to iodine penetration.

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_015_chunk1
evidence_span: The cladding material is Zircaloy-2, which was originally in the cold-worked/stress-relieved condition.

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_015_chunk1
evidence_span: Rod No. JJ 400002, Specimen No. prefix 165 F, Cladding material cold-worked, stress-relieved Zircaloy-2, Burnup 8.4 GWd/t, Cladding outside diameter 9.66 mm, Wall thickness 0.86 mm, Fission-gas release 14.3 %, Inside-diameter surface oxide 3 to 4 (breached) μm

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_015_chunk1
evidence_span: Rod No. JJ 400002, Specimen No. prefix 165 F, Cladding material cold-worked, stress-relieved Zircaloy-2, Burnup 8.4 GWd/t, Cladding outside diameter 9.66 mm, Wall thickness 0.86 mm, Fission-gas release 14.3 %, Inside-diameter surface oxide 3 to 4 (breached) μm

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_015_chunk1
evidence_span: Rod No. JK 400001, Specimen No. prefix 165 E, Burnup 7.2 GWd/t, Cladding outside diameter 9.66 mm, Wall thickness 0.86 mm, Fission-gas release 0.2 %, Inside-diameter surface oxide 3 to 4 (unbreached) μm

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_015_chunk2
evidence_span: The cladding specimens were tested in-cell under biaxial stress conditions and in the presence of iodine to determine susceptibility to SCC

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_015_chunk2
evidence_span: The specimens, nominally $1 5 0  \ \mathrm { m m }$ long

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_015_chunk2
evidence_span: About 98 percent of the inner volume of the specimen is displaced by two Vycor rods and two zirconium end plugs

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_015_chunk2
evidence_span: A glass ampule containing $2 5 ~ \mathsf { m g }$ of iodine is located between the Vycor rods

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_015_chunk2
evidence_span: The nominal concentration of iodine is $0 . 6 ~ \mathrm { m g } / \mathrm { c m } ^ { 2 }$

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_015_chunk2
evidence_span: The total volume of the pressurization gas is estimated to be 85 $\mathsf { c m } ^ { 3 }$

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_015_chunk2
evidence_span: All tests were conducted at $3 2 5 \mathrm { ^ \circ C }$

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_015_chunk2
evidence_span: The pressure and temperature were monitored continuously during the tests and controlled to $\pm 0 . 3$ percent and $\pm 2$ deg C, respectively

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_015_chunk2
evidence_span: Argon (99.99 percent pure) was used as the pressurization gas

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_015_chunk2
evidence_span: The estimated uncertainty in the values of the hoop stress is $\pm 2$ percent

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_015_chunk2
evidence_span: The test stresses ranged from 180 to $3 2 0  \ \mathrm { M P a }$

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_015_chunk2
evidence_span: An SCC test consisted of heating a sealed specimen to $3 2 5 \mathrm { { \circ } } _ { \mathrm { C } }$ and then pressurizing it to the desired hoop stress

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_015_chunk2
evidence_span: These tests were run at a constant stress for a period of $3 . 6 \times 1 0 ^ { 4 }$ to $8 . 6 4 \times 1 0 ^ { 4 } \mathrm { s }$ (10 to 24 h)

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_015_chunk2
evidence_span: specimens from Rod 165E exhibiting a threshold stress of $\sim 2 8 0$ MPa

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_015_chunk2
evidence_span: $\sim 2 0 0$ MPa for Rod 165F

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_015_chunk2
evidence_span: The failure strains in specimens that failed in either the pinhole or small-crack mode ranged from undetectable for specimens from Rod 165F to 0.19 percent for Specimen 165E4

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_015_chunk2
evidence_span: 0.19 percent for Specimen 165E4

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_015_chunk2
evidence_span: The subsequent introduction of $2 5 { \mathrm { ~ m g } }$ of iodine resulted in a failure at $2 0 5 \mathrm { M P a }$ after $\dot { 3 } . 1 \times 1 0 ^ { 4 } \ : s$ (8.6 h)

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_015_chunk2
evidence_span: high-burnup $( { \sim } 2 4  \ \mathrm { G W } \mathsf { d } / \mathsf { t } )$ Big Rock Point (BRP) fuel rods

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_015_chunk2
evidence_span: The inside-diameter surface oxide was nonuniform, ranging from ${ \sim } 1 8$ $\mu \mathrm { m }$ thick in isolated areas to below detectability in other areas

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_015_chunk2
evidence_span: The BRP curve indicates that the threshold stress for specimens from both rods is above that of other cladding

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_015_chunk2
evidence_span: the threshold stress for cladding from Rod 165E is close to that of unirradiated cold-worked stress-relieved cladding

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_015_chunk2
evidence_span: The total length of the failure along the inside diameter is ${ \sim } 9 ~ \mathrm { m m }$

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_015_chunk4
evidence_span: Several control tests on irradiated cladding without iodine have been conducted. The cladding used for these tests is from the Oskarshamn I reactor

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_015_chunk4
evidence_span: failure stress of ~160 MPa for the tests conducted in iodine

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_015_chunk4
evidence_span: by varying the total iodine content from 5 to 100 mg, the failure stress could be changed about 10 percent for unirradiated, autoclaved material (1 μm oxide)

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_015_chunk4
evidence_span: failure time at the same stress level could change from 1 to 100 h

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_015_chunk4
evidence_span: By increasing the amount of iodine from 5 to 55 mg for irradiated cladding, the failure stress was reduced from 500 to 250 MPa

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_015_chunk4
evidence_span: at the cladding operating temperatures (~300°C)

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_015_chunk4
evidence_span: if fuel rod cladding were protected with an intact oxide layer, then higher stress levels would be needed to initiate a stress corrosion crack

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_015_chunk5
evidence_span: Tests were conducted at $3 4 3 ^ { \circ } \mathbf { C }$ with external pressures from 13.3 to $1 8 . 7 \mathbf { M P a }$

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_015_chunk5
evidence_span: Tests were conducted at $3 4 3 ^ { \circ } \mathbf { C }$ with external pressures from 13.3 to $1 8 . 7 \mathbf { M P a }$

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_015_chunk5
evidence_span: Three of the specimens were subjected to stress reversal during their test runs, wherein they were pressurized internally from 3.5 to $6 . 9 \mathbf { M P a }$

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_015_chunk5
evidence_span: Three of the specimens were subjected to stress reversal during their test runs, wherein they were pressurized internally from 3.5 to $6 . 9 \mathbf { M P a }$

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_015_chunk5
evidence_span: Fast flux $[ E > 1 . 0  { \mathrm { M e V } } ( 0 . 2  { \mathbf { p } }  { \mathbf { J } } ) ]$ ranged from $3 . 8 \times 1 0 ^ { 1 7 }$ to ${ \bf 5 . 0 \times 1 0 ^ { 1 7 } }$ neutrons $( \mathbf { n } ) / ( \mathbf { m } ^ { 2 } \cdot \mathbf { s } )$

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_015_chunk5
evidence_span: Maximum fluence was approximately $7 \times 1 0 ^ { 2 5 } \mathrm { n } / \mathrm { m } ^ { 2 }$

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_015_chunk5
evidence_span: the in-reactor specimens did not deform uniformly, that is, by diametral contraction and smooth ovalization

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_015_chunk5
evidence_span: the deformation surfaces were nonuniform with hills and valleys being formed at irregular intervals
